full_title: U-Net: Convolutional Networks for Biomedical Image Segmentation
authors: Olaf Ronneberger, Philipp Fischer, Thomas Brox
tagline: Encoder窶電ecoder CNN with skip connections; a strong grid-to-grid baseline for PDE field reconstruction.
tldr: U-Net is a symmetric encoder窶電ecoder convolutional network with skip connections that fuse high-resolution features from the encoder into the decoder. While originally proposed for biomedical segmentation, it is widely used as a baseline for dense prediction on grids (including PDE surrogate modeling and masked field reconstruction).
problem: Provide a fast, high-quality mapping from input images/tensors to output images/tensors when locality and multi-scale context matter. In AI4PDE, U-Net is a common baseline for grid-based surrogates and inpainting.
benefits: Strong locality + multi-scale inductive bias; often competitive with more complex models on image-like PDE grids.
Easy to train and deploy; compatible with many conditioning signals via concatenation.
Good default backbone for diffusion denoisers and PDE inpainting models.
theory: Skip connections preserve fine spatial detail while allowing deep receptive fields through downsampling.
contrib: Introduced the now-standard U-shaped encoder窶電ecoder with skip connections for dense prediction.
Demonstrated strong segmentation performance with limited labeled data via heavy data augmentation.
setting: Convolution + ReLU blocks with max-pooling downsampling.
Skip connections concatenate encoder feature maps into decoder.

results_tables.title: Why it is used in AI4PDE
rows: Fast grid-to-grid mapping; strong locality bias
Skip connections preserve detail in inpainting tasks
Standard U-Net is a strong denoising architecture

interesting: Many diffusion models use a U-Net backbone; this makes U-Net a key baseline component for generative PDE inference.
